items.title: Four dead after fire engulfs residential high-rise buildings in Hong Kong
items.standfirst: Several people reportedly trapped inside burning towers as firefighters tackle huge blaze in Tai Po districtFour people have died after a massive fire engulfed several high-rise towers of a residential complex in Hong Kong’s northern Tai Po district, with thick grey smoke billowing out as emergency services tackled the blaze.Several people remained trapped inside the burning towers, the public broadcaster RTHK reported, citing police, while two people were in a critical condition having suffered severe burns, it said. Continue reading...

items.title: US to send envoy to Moscow to discuss proposals to end Ukraine war
items.standfirst: Despite recent efforts and White House optimism, recent negotiations have failed to secure a breakthrough on key issuesDonald Trump said he would send special envoy Steve Witkoff to meet Vladimir Putin in Moscow to discuss developing proposals to end the Ukraine war, but despite White House optimism there was little sign of progress on core sticking points.The US president said negotiations had left “only a few remaining points of disagreement” but there was no breakthrough on the issues of territorial control and security guarantees and he dampened expectations of immediate peace summits. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump is sending senior negotiators to meet Vladimir Putin to push for a deal to end Russia’s war.
items.content: US President Donald Trump is sending senior negotiators to meet Vladimir Putin to push for a deal to end Russia’s war.

items.title: Trump envoy Witkoff reportedly advised Kremlin official on Ukraine peace deal
items.standfirst: Steve Witkoff spoke to Yuri Ushakov on territorial control and suggested congratulating Donald Trump and framing talks more optimistically, audio recording suggestsDonald Trump’s special envoy Steve Witkoff told a senior Kremlin official last month that achieving peace in Ukraine would require Russia gaining control of Donetsk and potentially a separate territorial exchange, according to a recording of their conversation obtained by Bloomberg.In the 14 October phone call with Yuri Ushakov, the top foreign policy aide to the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, Witkoff said he believed the land concessions were necessary all while advising Ushakov to congratulate Trump and frame discussions more optimistically. Continue reading...
items.content: Steve Witkoff spoke to Yuri Ushakov on territorial control and suggested congratulating Donald Trump and framing talks more optimistically, audio recording suggestsDonald Trump’s special envoy Steve Witkoff told a senior Kremlin official last month that achieving peace in Ukraine would require Russia gaining control of Donetsk and potentially a separate territorial exchange, according to a recording of their conversation obtained by Bloomberg.In the 14 October phone call with Yuri Ushakov, the top foreign policy aide to the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, Witkoff said he believed the land concessions were necessary all while advising Ushakov to congratulate Trump and frame discussions more optimistically. items.title: Live: Kremlin confirms US envoy Witkoff to visit as Trump eases peace plan deadline
items.standfirst: The Kremlin has confirmed next week's visit by US envoy Steve Witkoff to meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin. President Donald Trump has also said he would send Army Secretary Dan Driscoll to meet with Ukrainian officials as he seeks to close out a deal to end the war in Ukraine. Trump said his proposed peace plan had been “fine-tuned”, backed away from setting a firm deadline, and said his son-in-law Jared Kushner may join Witkoff in Moscow. Follow our liveblog for the latest updates.
items.content: The Kremlin has confirmed next week's visit by US envoy Steve Witkoff to meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin. President Donald Trump has also said he would send Army Secretary Dan Driscoll to meet with Ukrainian officials as he seeks to close out a deal to end the war in Ukraine. Trump said his proposed peace plan had been “fine-tuned”, backed away from setting a firm deadline, and said his son-in-law Jared Kushner may join Witkoff in Moscow. Follow our liveblog for the latest updates.

items.title: US envoy Witkoff advised Russia on getting Trump to Ukraine deal, Bloomberg reports
items.standfirst: US envoy Steve Witkoff advised the Kremlin on how Russian President Vladimir Putin should negotiate a deal on Ukraine with President Donald Trump in mid-October, Bloomberg reported Tuesday. A 28-point US peace proposal was widely seen as favouring Russia, requiring Ukraine to make large territorial concessions and renounce its NATO ambitions.
items.content: US envoy Steve Witkoff advised the Kremlin on how Russian President Vladimir Putin should negotiate a deal on Ukraine with President Donald Trump in mid-October, Bloomberg reported Tuesday. A 28-point US peace proposal was widely seen as favouring Russia, requiring Ukraine to make large territorial concessions and renounce its NATO ambitions.

items.title: Zelenskyy ready to meet Trump to discuss Ukraine peace plan
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy told European leaders that talks in Geneva had produced a framework for peace to discuss with President Trump, but insisted there would need to be clear evidence that “Russia is serious about ending this war of aggression.”
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy told European leaders that talks in Geneva had produced a framework for peace to discuss with President Trump, but insisted there would need to be clear evidence that “Russia is serious about ending this war of aggression.”

The Kremlin confirmed Witkoff's upcoming meeting with Putin.
Trump's envoy reportedly advised a Kremlin official on the peace deal.

clusters.title: Bolsonaro ordered to start serving 27-year prison sentence for Brazil coup plot
clusters.neutral_headline: Bolsonaro Ordered to Begin 27-Year Prison Sentence

items.title: Bolsonaro ordered to start serving 27-year prison sentence for Brazil coup plot
items.standfirst: The Supreme Court says the former leader has exhausted his appeals and will start his prison term at a police station in Brasilia.
items.content: The Supreme Court says the former leader has exhausted his appeals and will start his prison term at a police station in Brasilia.

items.title: Brazil's Bolsonaro begins 27-year jail term for coup bid
items.standfirst: Brazil's Supreme Court on Tuesday ordered far-right former president Jair Bolsonaro to begin serving a 27-year sentence for plotting a failed coup, after he exhausted all appeals. The brash former army captain who fired up Brazil's right and reshaped the country's politics is ending a divisive career jailed in a small room at police headquarters equipped with a TV, mini-fridge, and air-conditioning.
items.content: Brazil's Supreme Court on Tuesday ordered far-right former president Jair Bolsonaro to begin serving a 27-year sentence for plotting a failed coup, after he exhausted all appeals. The brash former army captain who fired up Brazil's right and reshaped the country's politics is ending a divisive career jailed in a small room at police headquarters equipped with a TV, mini-fridge, and air-conditioning.

items.title: Brazil's former President Jair Bolsonaro begins 27-year prison sentence for coup attempt
items.standfirst: Former Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro on Tuesday started his 27-year prison sentence for leading a coup attempt, to the surprise of many in the South American nation who doubted he would ever end up behind bars. Supreme Court Justice Alexandre de Moraes, who has overseen the case, ruled Bolsonaro will remain in custody after being preemptively arrested on Saturday. FRANCE 24's Jan Onoszko reports from Rio de Janeiro.
items.content: Former Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro on Tuesday started his 27-year prison sentence for leading a coup attempt, to the surprise of many in the South American nation who doubted he would ever end up behind bars. Supreme Court Justice Alexandre de Moraes, who has overseen the case, ruled Bolsonaro will remain in custody after being preemptively arrested on Saturday. FRANCE 24's Jan Onoszko reports from Rio de Janeiro.

items.title: Brazil's Bolsonaro begins 27-year prison sentence
items.standfirst: Former Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro has started a 27-year prison sentence for leading a coup attempt after losing the 2022 presidential election.
items.content: Former Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro has started a 27-year prison sentence for leading a coup attempt after losing the 2022 presidential election.

items.title: Jair Bolsonaro ordered to start 27-year prison term for plotting Brazil coup
items.standfirst: Ex-president to start serving term in 12 sq metre bedroom in police base in Brasília after time for appeals elapsesBrazil’s former president, Jair Bolsonaro, has been ordered to start serving his 27-year sentence in a 12 sq metre bedroom in a police base in the capital, Brasília, after his conviction for plotting a coup.The far-right populist, 70, who governed Latin America’s largest democracy from 2019 until 2022, was handed the punishment in September after the supreme court found him guilty of leading a criminal conspiracy to stop his leftwing rival, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, taking power. Continue reading...
items.content: Ex-president to start serving term in 12 sq metre bedroom in police base in Brasília after time for appeals elapsesBrazil’s former president, Jair Bolsonaro, has been ordered to start serving his 27-year sentence in a 12 sq metre bedroom in a police base in the capital, Brasília, after his conviction for plotting a coup.The far-right populist, 70, who governed Latin America’s largest democracy from 2019 until 2022, was handed the punishment in September after the supreme court found him guilty of leading a criminal conspiracy to stop his leftwing rival, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, taking power. Continue reading...

The sentence is for plotting a failed coup attempt.
Bolsonaro was arrested after losing the 2022 election.

items.content: A woman has been jailed for life in New Zealand for murdering her two children, whose bodies were found in suitcases in an abandoned storage unit more than three years ago.

items.standfirst: Hakyung Lee was found guilty of murdering her children and concealing their remains in a storage lockerA mother who murdered her two children and hid their bodies in suitcases stored inside a rented locker has been sentenced to life imprisonment in New Zealand.Hakyung Lee, a New Zealand citizen originally from South Korea, was found guilty earlier this year of killing her children in a crime that has become known as the “suitcase murders”. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

clusters.title: Floods kill dozens, displace thousands in southern Thailand
clusters.neutral_headline: Flooding in Thailand Kills Dozens, Displaces Thousands

items.title: Floods kill dozens, displace thousands in southern Thailand
items.standfirst: Flooding in southern Thailand kills 33 people and displaces more than 10,000 as heavy rains batter seven provinces.
items.content: Flooding in southern Thailand kills 33 people and displaces more than 10,000 as heavy rains batter seven provinces.

items.title: Two million affected by Thailand floods
items.standfirst: Severe flooding in southern Thailand has killed 33 people and displaced tens of thousands, also affecting neighbouring Malaysia. A state of emergency has been declared in Songkhla province, where heavy rains have inundated Hat Yai and surrounding areas. In total, about two million people have been affected by the flooding. FRANCE 24's correspondent in the region has more.
items.content: Severe flooding in southern Thailand has killed 33 people and displaced tens of thousands, also affecting neighbouring Malaysia. A state of emergency has been declared in Songkhla province, where heavy rains have inundated Hat Yai and surrounding areas. In total, about two million people have been affected by the flooding. FRANCE 24's correspondent in the region has more.

items.title: Southern Thailand floods kill 33, leave thousands stranded
items.standfirst: Floods have left thousands of people stranded and large areas under water in southern Thailand and northern Malaysia.
items.content: Floods have left thousands of people stranded and large areas under water in southern Thailand and northern Malaysia.

ai_summary: Flooding in southern Thailand killed 33 people.
Over 10,000 people were displaced by the floods.

items.title: Pets at Home boss says ‘urgent and necessary’ action needed as profits dive
items.standfirst: Interim chair of group, which is still looking for a CEO, says chain must ‘return to our retailing roots’The boss of Pets at Home has said “urgent and necessary” action needs to be taken as the ailing retailer reported that its half-year profits slumped by more than a third.The group is still looking for a chief executive after the abrupt departure of Lyssa McGowan in September. The interim executive chair, Ian Burke, said the chain, which sells pet products, animals, veterinary care and grooming services, had to “return to our retaining roots” to revitalise the 34-year-old business. Continue reading...
items.content: Interim chair of group, which is still looking for a CEO, says chain must ‘return to our retailing roots’The boss of Pets at Home has said “urgent and necessary” action needs to be taken as the ailing retailer reported that its half-year profits slumped by more than a third.The group is still looking for a chief executive after the abrupt departure of Lyssa McGowan in September. The interim executive chair, Ian Burke, said the chain, which sells pet products, animals, veterinary care and grooming services, had to “return to our retaining roots” to revitalise the 34-year-old business. Continue reading...

items.title: US and Israel-backed Gaza Humanitarian Foundation to end operations in territory
items.standfirst: Four main food distribution sites operated by the opaque company had been flashpoints of deadly violence A controversial and secretive private company backed by the US and Israel that distributed food in Gaza has announced the end of its operations in the devastated territory.The Gaza Humanitarian Foundation (GHF), which had four food distribution sites that became flashpoints of chaos and deadly violence between May and October, said in a statement that it would shut down permanently, having “successfully completed its emergency mission”.
